title: Quiz 4: Quantitative Methodologies
description: Test your grasp of quantitative designs, including experimental, quasi-experimental, and survey methods.

questions.question: What are the three major characteristics of a 'True Experimental' research design? (Select 3)
questions.explanation: True experimental research requires strict adherence to Control, Manipulation (of the independent variable), and Randomisation.

questions.question: Which design aims to examine causality but lacks full control or randomization?
questions.explanation: Quasi-experimental designs are used when complete control (like randomization) is not possible but the researcher still wants to test an intervention.

questions.question: Match the time-dimensional study type to its description:

pairs.right: Conducted over a long duration (e.g., Cohort study)
Conducted at one point in time (Snapshot)
Looks back to link present with the past
Starts in present and looks into the future

questions.question: ___BLANK___ research is the systematic collection and presentation of data to give a clear picture of a particular situation, often generating new knowledge for future research.
questions.explanation: Descriptive research describes 'what is' without manipulating variables.

questions.question: In a survey design, the researcher manipulates the independent variable to see its effect on the dependent variable.
questions.explanation: Surveys are descriptive; they do NOT involve manipulation. Manipulation is a feature of experimental designs.
questions.hint: Do you change anything in a survey, or just ask questions?

questions.question: Which of the following is a disadvantage of Experimental Research?

options.text: It is often expensive and difficult to conduct in real settings
It does not allow for prediction

questions.explanation: While powerful, experimental research is costly, time-consuming, and often impractical (difficult to control) in real-world nursing settings.

questions.question: Review the correlation graph descriptions. Which scenario represents a NEGATIVE correlation?

richContent.content:
• Scenario A: Smoking increases, Lung disease increases.
  • Scenario B: Tetanus vaccination increases, Tetanus infection decreases.
  • Scenario C: Teething happens, Diarrhea happens (no link).

questions.explanation: A negative correlation means as one variable increases (vaccination), the other decreases (infection). Scenario A is positive; C is no correlation.
questions.hint: One goes up, the other goes down.

questions.question: Order the level of control in research designs from LEAST to MOST control:
questions.explanation: Descriptive has no control; Quasi has some control; True Experimental has strict control.

questions.question: What is the specific term for the variable that the researcher manipulates or applies as a treatment?
questions.explanation: The Independent variable is the 'cause' or intervention manipulated by the researcher.
questions.hint: It stands alone and causes change.

questions.question: Which of the following are common data collection methods for Survey Research? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Surveys rely on asking people questions via questionnaires or interviews, not physical lab tests.
